none: Letter to Louis L. McInnis from W. R. Cavitt, January 11, 1887
Letter to Louis L. McInnis from W. R. Cavitt, January 11, 1887
Box 1 Louis L. McInnis Papers/Box 1 Folder 24 Louis L. McInnis Papers

body.value:
At Home (Bryan Texas) - Jan 11th 87-

Prof. L. L. McInnis.
College Station, Texas -

Friend McInnis,

Yours dated Yesterday rec'd - Thanks -
I want the $600 00/100 for 30 or 60 days - I
can give whatever landed security desired (if
wanted) - I will give lien on 300 acres
between here & College if wanted - You can
send money by ______ the Negro if convenient
I want it tomorrow - The bearer is
Andy Dixon (f.m.c.) - You give me amt
interest required, security &c & I will
send same out by tomorrow's mail - ______

Wish you would send me report of the
University Regents - I want to look over of
it before we have our Austin meeting -
You need not say to bearer anything
about contents if you send money -

Am still confined to my room - I hope
to be able to be out to College latter part
of this week.

As Ever Yours &c
W. R. Cavitt

**Here's how I approached this transcription task:** I began by understanding the requirements: transcribe text from an image of a handwritten document. My role is that of a transcriptionist, with the goal of high accuracy, including original spelling, punctuation, and layout. I need to interpret handwriting, maintain the document's structure with appropriate HTML markup (using the allowed elements only), and identify/label any structural elements like the header, footer, and signature. If there's any data presented in a table, I must use Markdown for it. I also must handle any marginalia or insertions in the text. I'm limited to providing only the transcribed text, with no additional commentary. Next, I analyzed the image. It's a handwritten letter in cursive from the late 19th century. The content is a request for a $600 loan for a specific timeframe (30-60 days) with land offered as security. It mentions a bearer named Andy Dixon and references the "University Regents." Additional context includes mention of illness or confinement to a room. The date and location are "At Home (Bryan Texas) - Jan 11th 87" (1887), and it's addressed to "Prof. L. L. McInnis, College Station, Texas." The sender is identified as "W. R. Cavitt," which, after careful visual analysis and cross-referencing with historical records, I've determined is the more likely reading of the signature, matching the historical context of a chairman of the Board of Directors of A&M College. I then started transcribing the text line by line. I have created blocks to represent the letter's format. I paid close attention to detail, considering each word and punctuation mark. I identified and transcribed the header, salutation, body paragraphs, and closing/signature. I noted and transcribed inserted text. I applied the HTML markup to maintain the document's structure, using `

` for paragraphs, and `
` for line breaks. Throughout this process, I considered nuances in the handwriting, such as the superscript "th" in "11th" and the raised "c" in "McInnis". I also accurately represented the formatting of the fraction "00/100" by using HTML tags. In the original transcription the word "Negro" has an underline, which I have noted in my process and represented. I used HTML markup to show insertions of text (carats) and other nuances of style. I did a final polish and self-corrected a few things to ensure accuracy. I had to interpret how to apply the guidelines. I had to look at "look over of" very carefully to make sure I got the words right. I then double-checked all elements to generate a final result that is an accurate and properly formatted transcription.
